messages: 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:30): hmm, looks like html5lib doesn't parse the contents of the noscript element
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:36): i don't understand this interest in splitting out html5 using this new scheme
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:36): i've never seen a spec do this before
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:37): (the "implementation" vs "authoring" split that some people want)

14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:38): that one doesn't make much sense to me either. DOM initialization vs. post DOM initialization is more sensible (parser/script dependencies notwithstanding). another more sensible split would be old stuff vs. new stuff
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:43): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: which "consistency and stability claims" are overblown and how are they overblown?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:44): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: also, how is the HTML5 change control unsatisfactory?

14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:45): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, well jgraham is claiming that the parser section is so stable that nothing further can happen without major browser implementation
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:45): yet html5lib doesn't even do what the spec says regarding noscript
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:45): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: i doubt he thinks that _nothing_ further can happen
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:46): "the parsing work is stable to the extent that it can be without having implementations in major-marketshare browsers"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:46): but it's certainly true that we're mostly just waiting for wide-scale implementation experience
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:46): well that's true
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:46): it's as stable as it can ever be without wide-scale implementation experience
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:46): that doesn't mean nothing further can happen
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:46): even a completely stable spec can change
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:47): just not much
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:47): even a shipped product (the epitomy of stable) can change, e.g. security fixes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:47): CSS2 was as stable as it gets, yet look at the amount of change _it_ went through
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:49): just saying there's an obvious delta between the spec and a library that most major html5 contributors have commit access to
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:50): surprised it could happen
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:50): really?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:50): dude, all software has bugs
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:50): all specs have bugs
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:50): well, surprised it's never even been noticed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:50): i hate to be the one to break it to you
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:52): 14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4: also, how is the HTML5 change control unsatisfactory?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:52): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, I don't like the explicit private feedback challenges
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:52): channels
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:53): yeah, nor do i
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:53): like, I am guessing you did not invent MessagePort
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:53): maybe I am wrong about that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:53): sadly, some people don't want to say anything in public because their products are secret, or whatnot
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:53): invent how?
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:53): it was quite different from the Apple and Mozilla proposals as I recall
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:54): proposals for what?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:54): do you mean the worker stuff?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:54): workers are unrelated to messageport really
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:54): though i did reuse them for that purpose since it seemed useful
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:55): well, at any rate, I never proposed a course of action
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:55): (messageport though, the api, was basically something i wrote up based on a series of proposals related to capabilities APIs through messages)
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:55): I just don't think other editorial splits are obviously bad
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:56): oh some are definitely good
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:56): like we should split out the storage stuff eventually
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:56): especially if someone is willing to do a document
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:56): since that's pretty self-contained
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:56): even if you don't suggest it
14af4ca97e316b17ea96286dc6882fd4 (04:56): anyway, gtg
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (04:56): later
